bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 5, 1890

div1.p: Lazear has received some U.S. newspapers. He discusses his plans for the next several weeks.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 5, 1890
div1.p:
Your letter of June 23
came the other day with an enormous
stack of papers, for besides the
Pittsburgh and New York papers that you
sent, there was the “Pittsburgh Post”
and three “Baltimore Sun's” which Aunt
Kate sent me. Of course I have not had
time to read them all but I will
try to read most of them to-morrow.

I am afraid you are spending a
small fortune in postage and
going to a great deal of trouble as well.
Yesterday morning I got a card
from Mrs. Hartman. In the evening
I went to the address given and
found that she had gone north, but
would be back to-day. I will
make another attempt to see her
this evening.

I hope your cold continued to improve
and that you have had no more
trouble with it since. You must take
care of yourself. Although we have
such bad weather here I have not
had a sign of a cold. The weather
is not at all changeable, it is
always cold and always rainy.

My busy time is drawing to a close
and I shall not be sorry for it
as I have kept at work A very
steadily ever since I got here.
I will write to Uncle Tom in a
few days. I have been intending to
all along but I have not had
the time and then I have seen
very little of the town and country
and I would have nothing to tell
him.

I may not stay in London the full two
weeks that I had intended, as I want
to hurry to Germany to spend as
much time as possible there. Still
I cannot tell, I may stay two weeks
and I may not, according to how
I find it there. Direct letters to
London for two weeks as I said
and if I do not stay that long
I will have them forwarded.
You have never said anything about
about what I should get for a
wedding present to Jess and Chrissie
I wish you would suggest one
or two things.

I have not been any place since
I last wrote. I have added a
new trip to the list of things I am
going to do, It is a steamboat
trip down to the mouth of the Forth
around Bass Rock. The trip only
costs a shilling. but it takes a
whole afternoon and I have not
any afternoons to spare until after
Sir William Turners last examination
which comes on next Tuesday.

I have not yet been to any of
the churches here. But I can easily
see all I that I want in one
Sunday as they all hold five
different services.
